President Trump is set to meet German Chancellor Angela Merkel this week at the White House, marking the first face-to-face encounter between the new U.S. commander in chief and the woman known as “Europe’s decider.” When they meet, the two leaders with little in common will find themselves belatedly moving to forge a relationship that could determine the future of transatlantic ties.

Trump took swipes at Merkel during the election campaign, decrying her refugee policy as “a sad, sad shame.” For her part, Merkel — who was considered Obama’s closest ally in Europe — responded with a congratulatory message after Trump’s victory that seemed to school him on the importance of democratic values.

Therefore, the chancellor needs to convey a certain coolness to show that this won’t cut it with her.”

Merkel is set to talk to Trump alone for about 30 minutes when she arrives at the White House on Friday.

Underscoring how communication between the two sides may yet need a bit of work, a German official close to Merkel said that a firm new date had not been officially confirmed and that Merkel would meet Trump “soon.”

That Merkel and Trump are off to a rocky start is no secret.

Locked in a tougher-than-expected bid for reelection this year, she must somehow demonstrate that she is willing to stand up for European values and positions, while also making nice with a trash-talking businessman-turned-president who is deeply unpopular among Germans.

Whether Trump accepts that gift is anybody’s guess, and Merkel’s visit will undoubtedly spotlight the serious concerns in Berlin about his unconventional presidency.
“Merkel wants to demonstrate to the political world in Germany and Europe that she can handle Trump,” said Josef Janning, head of the Berlin office of the European Council on Foreign Relations.
They include fears of a looming trade war and of undermining the European Union, as well as worries of roughshod decision-making in the Middle East that could provoke another refugee crisis.
Asked whether Merkel would address Trump’s plan to build a wall along the U.S. border with Mexico, one German official said the chancellor would not interfere in U.S. domestic politics.
The Germans have grown highly sensitive to the Trump administration’s jabs about Germany’s export surplus, as well as suggestions that an artificially weak euro is unfairly aiding them.
“Many jobs in Germany depend on exports, so we do have a lot to lose with protectionism,” said a German official who spoke on the customary condition of anonymity to be candid.
Now, weeks after Trump’s meetings with the leaders of other nations, including Japan and Britain, Merkel arrives in Washington with perhaps more to lose than to gain.
